title: 114_hr3602
content: The Act is titled the "Gold King Mine Spill Recovery Act of 2015". On August 5, 2015, 3,000,000 gallons of contaminated water was discharged from the Gold King Mine into Cement Creek, a tributary of the Animas River. The discharge was caused by EPA contractors investigating the mine for ongoing water releases, mine water treatment, and mine remediation feasibility. The contaminated water contained high levels of heavy metals like aluminum, arsenic, cadmium, copper, lead, and mercury. On August 5, 2015, 3,000,000 gallons of contaminated water from the Gold King Mine flowed into the Animas River, San Juan River, and Lake Powell. State of emergency declarations were made by Colorado, New Mexico, Utah, and the Navajo Nation. The EPA will take full responsibility for the discharge. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Administrator" refers to the head of the Environmental Protection Agency. The term "Gold King Mine spill" describes the release of contaminated water from the Gold King Mine in Colorado on August 5, 2015. An "injured person" is someone who suffered harm from the spill, including individuals and Indian tribes. An "injured person" is defined as someone who suffered harm from the Gold King Mine spill, including individuals, Indian tribes, corporations, and other non-Federal entities. Injury refers to any damage to property, personal injury, or death caused by the spill. The Office of Gold King Mine Spill Claims handles claims for loss of property, personal injury, or death caused by negligence of Federal officers, employees, contractors, or subcontractors. The office is established by section 4(b)(1). SEC. 4. COMPENSATION FOR VICTIMS OF GOLD KING MINE SPILL. Each injured person is entitled to compensation under the Federal Tort Claims Act for injuries resulting from the Gold King Mine spill. Acceptance of compensation has the same effect as under other laws. The Administrator and Attorney General will process claims and civil actions. The General will process claims related to injuries from the Gold King Mine spill promptly. The limitation on claim amounts is waived, and compensation over $25,000 can be provided without prior approval. An Office of Gold King Mine Spill Claims is established. The Office of Gold King Mine Spill Claims is established within the Environmental Protection Agency to receive, process, and pay claims. The Administrator can request personnel from other federal departments to assist in carrying out duties. Allowable damages for property loss claims may include otherwise-uncompensated losses. Allowable damages for property loss claims under this section may include costs for lost tribal subsistence activities, reforestation or revegetation on tribal or non-Federal land, and costs incurred to determine damages to agricultural land or other damages covered by the Act. The Act allows for property loss claims to cover damages such as costs for lost tribal subsistence activities, reforestation, damages to agricultural land, and other damages. Business loss claims may include damages from the Gold King Mine spill like damage to assets, business interruption losses, overhead costs, and employee wages for work not performed. Financial loss claims under the Act for damages resulting from the Gold King Mine spill may include insurance deductibles, lost wages, emergency staffing expenses, debris removal costs, and other financial losses determined appropriate by the Administrator. SEC. 5. Long-term water quality monitoring program established as Superfund site. The Administrator will work with affected States and tribes to develop a long-term monitoring program for water quality in response to the Gold King Mine spill. The program will include full disclosure of water quality data and comparison to relevant standards. Congress suggests consulting with local communities and tribes affected by the spill. The Administrator will collaborate with Navajo Nation, the Southern Ute Indian Tribe, Colorado, and New Mexico to consider listing the Upper Animas River watershed on the National Priorities List. They will also prioritize building a water treatment plant in the Upper Animas River basin to reduce heavy metal discharge into the Animas River from Cement Creek. SEC. 6. AMENDMENT TO CERCLA. Title I of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 is amended by adding SEC. 129. MINING-RELATED PROVISIONS. The Administrator, Secretary of Agriculture, and Secretary of the Interior, along with other relevant entities, must review dangerous abandoned and inactive mines to prioritize removal and remediation of hazardous substances within 180 days of enactment. The text chunk discusses the need for prioritizing the removal and remediation of hazardous substances and pollutants from closed, abandoned, and inactive mines. It also mentions the development of a long-term research initiative to evaluate the attributes of such mines and pursue technological advancements for cleanup. Additionally, it outlines the actions required before conducting any activity at a mine with the potential for accidental discharge of pollutants. The text chunk emphasizes the importance of developing spill prevention plans for activities that may result in discharge of pollutants, ensuring resources are provided to affected tribal, State, and local governments. SEC. 7. EFFECT OF ACT. This Act does not provide compensation for any injured person from the Hazardous Substances Superfund.
